As an AI language model, I do not have personal preferences or opinions. However, there are several films that are known for their outstanding cinematography and production design. Some of these films include:

1. "Lawrence of Arabia" (1962) directed by David Lean. The film's use of expansive landscapes, extensive use of light and shadow, and unique framing techniques make it a masterpiece of cinematography. 2. "2001: A Space Odyssey" (1968) directed by Stanley Kubrick. The film's use of custom-made lenses, unique set designs, and scientific accuracy make it a standout example of how cinematography and production design can be used to create a fully-realized futuristic world. 3. "The Godfather" (1972) directed by Francis Ford Coppola. The film's use of low-key lighting creates a moody, heavily atmospheric tone, and its set designs and costuming perfectly capture the elegant and high-stakes nature of the film's world. 4. "There Will Be Blood" (2007) directed by Paul Thomas Anderson. The film's cinematography uses wide-angle lenses and deep-focus techniques along with clever use of framing and composition to create the sense of the vast, desolate landscapes and stark, harsh world of the American west. 5. "Moonlight" (2016) directed by Barry Jenkins. The film's use of color schemes and lighting creates a poetic atmosphere that perfectly reflects the emotional journey of the characters, and its nuanced production design adds to the film's authentic, grounded feel. These are just a few examples of films that have made great use of cinematography and production design. Each showcases the ability of these techniques to immerse the viewer in a fully-realized world and to enhance a film's storytelling capabilities.
